acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 3 from 96 hours LC50=52mg/L of the fish (Rainbow Trout) (EU-RAR (2002) and others.).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "liquid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: Based on the LC50 value (4 hours) of 399ppm, representing the lower of the two testing data of rat LC50 (4 hour inhalation of vapour) of 0.948mg/L (EHC 56 (1985)) and 4.1mg/L (EHC 56 (1985)), was lower than 90% of the saturated vapor concentration (580,000ppm) under a saturated vapour pressure of 59kPa (20degC) (ICSC (1999)), the substance was considered as "vapour containing substantially no mist" and was classified based on standard values expressed in ppm.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the testing data of rat LD50 (oral route) of 1,140mg/kg (EHC 56 (1985)), 520mg/kg (EHC 56 (1985)).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Category R by NTP (2005), Group 2B by IARC (1994), Category A3 by ACGIH (2001) and Category B2 by EPA (1994).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since there was rapidly degrading (the decomposition by BOD: 96% (Existing Chemical Safety Inspections Data)) and the bio-accumulation was low (log Kow=0.03 (PHYSPROP Database, 2005)), it was claasified into Not classified.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to gaseous substances are not available - boiling point: 34degC (ICSC, 1999), test temperature: 55degC

explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: The flash point is -37degC (c.c.) (ICSC, 1999) and the boiling point is 34degC, which is classified into Category 1. Classified into Class 3 and Packing Group I (UN#1280) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

flammable_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on negative data on multi-generation mutagenicity tests (dominant lethal tests), the absence of data on germ cell mutagenicity in vivo, positive data on somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo (micronucleus tests and chromosome aberration tests), and the absence of data on germ cell genotoxicity tests in vivo, described in CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.47 (2004).

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Organic compounds containing oxygen (but not fluorine and chlorine), with the oxygen bound to carbon and hydrogen (but not to other elements)

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Not pyrophoric when in contact with air at ordinary temperatures; the auto-ignition temperature is 449degC (ICSC, 1999)

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale: Based on the description in the report on rat reproductive toxicity tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.47 (2004)): Effects on female infertility are observed (though no description is available for general toxicity), while the number of corpora lutea decreases at dosing levels inducing general toxicity.

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available

self_reactive_substances.rationale: No data available, though containing a distorted ring structure. Classified into Class 3 (UN#1280) by UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the classification into Category 1 (Corrosive Substances).

skin_corrosion_irritation.hazard_statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in the report on rabbit skin irritation tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.47 (2004)): The substance is corrosive to the skin.

skin_sensitizer.hazard_statement: May cause an allergic skin reaction
skin_sensitizer.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Skin sensitization by ACGIH (2001).

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the fact that the results are derived solely from inhalation exposure tests, though dosing levels inducing general toxicity are "not classified."

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause respiratory irritation (respiratory tract irritation)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "pulmonary/eye irritation, headache, hyposthenia, diarrhea, cyanosis" (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.47 (2004)), and the evidence from animal studies including "dyspnea and nasal hemorrhage." Symptoms such as headache and hyposthenia are considered the secondary effects caused by cyanosis.
